Description: Pseudonymised SSNAP Routinely Admitting team unique identifier
Pseudonymised patient unique identifier
Total number of team transfers, excluding community teams
Age on arrival aggregated to 5 year bands
Whether the patient is >= 80 years old at the moment of the stroke
Gender
Patient Ethnicity. Aggregated to White, Black, Mixed, Asian and Other
Whether the patient was already an inpatient at the time of stroke
Time from symptom onset to arrival at hospital in minutes, where known and if out of hospital stroke
Whether the date of onset given is precise, best estimate or if the stroke occurred while sleep
Whether the time of symptom onset given is precise, best estimate, not known
Whether the patient arrived by ambulance
Hour of arrival, aggregates to 3 hour epochs
Day of week at the moment of admission
Year quarter (Q1: Jan-Mar; Q2:April-Jun; Q3: Jul-Sept; Q4: Oct-Dec)
Year of admission
Comorbidbities: Pre-Stroke Congestive Heart Failure
Comorbidbities: Pre-Stroke Systemic Hypertension
Comorbidities: Pre-Stroke Atrial Fibrillation (persistent, permanent, or paroxysmal)
Comorbidities: Pre-Stroke Diabetes Mellitus
Comorbidities: Pre-Stroke history of stroke or Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA)
Only available if "Yes" to Atrial Fibrillation (Q2.1.3). Whether the patient was on antiplatelet medication prior to admission

Prior to 01-Dec-2017: Only available if "Yes" to Atrial Fibrillation (Q2.1.3); From 01-Dec-2017: available even if patient is not in Atrial Fibrillation prior to admission. Whether the patient was on anticoagulant medication prior to admission
If the patient was receiving anticoagulant medication, was it vitamin K antagonists
If the patient was receiving anticoagulant medication, was it direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs)
If the patient was receiving anticoagulant medication, was it Heparin
Patient's International Normalised ratio (INR) on arrival at hospital (available since 01-Dec-2017)
INR was greater than 10 on arrival at hospital (available since 01-Dec-2017)
INR not checked (available since 01-Dec-2017)
Whether a new diagnosis of Atrial Fibrillation was made on admission
Patient's modified Rankin Scale score before this stroke (Higher values indicate more disability)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score on arrival at hospital
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 1a Level of Consciousness (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 1b Level of Consciousness Questions (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 1c Level of Consciousness Commands (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 2 Best Gaze (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 3 Visual Fields (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 4 Facial Paresis (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 5a Motor Arm - Left (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 5b Motor Arm - Right (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 6a Motor Leg - Left (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 6b Motor Leg - Right (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 7 Limb Ataxia (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 8 Sensory (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 9 Best Language (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 10 Dysarthria (higher values indicate more severe deficit)
National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale Item 11 Extinction and Inattention (higher values indicate more severe deficit)

Time from Clock Start to brain scan. In minutes. "Clock Start" is used throughout SSNAP reporting to refer to the date and time of arrival at first hospital for newly arrived patients, or to the date and time of symptom onset if patient already in hospital at the time of their stroke.
Whether the stroke type was infarction or primary intracerebral haemorrhage
Whether the patient was given thrombolysis (clot busting medication)
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Haemorrhagic stroke
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Age
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Co-morbidity
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Medication
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Refusal
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Age
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Symptoms Improving
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Stroke too mild or too severe
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Symptom onset time unknown/wake-up stroke
If the answer to question 2.6 was "no but", the reason was Other medical reason

Time from Clock Start to thrombolysis. In minutes. "Clock Start" is used throughout SSNAP reporting to refer to the date and time of arrival at first hospital for newly arrived patients, or to the date and time of symptom onset if patient already in hospital at the time of their stroke.
Whether the patient had a Transient Ischaemic Attack during the last month. Item from the SSNAP comprehensive dataset questions (not mandatory)
